results.description: This constellation explores media works that manipulate time, specifically by utitlising a reverse play structure to tell a story.

key_work.title: The Gardens Between
key_work.brief_description: Following the relationship between two childhood friends, Ariana and Frendt, each level is full of objects that tease out shared memories and moments in time. Players don’t control the characters per se, but they instead use the game’s time-based mechanic to fast forwards or backwards.

constellations_primary.name: Time to rewind (The Gardens Between)
constellations_primary.description: This constellation explores media works that manipulate time, specifically by utitlising a reverse play structure to tell a story.

constellations_other.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_other.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

start.title: In Love (2001)
start.brief_description:
Much as Janine Antoni, Sally Mann, and Gillian Wearing have explored the sexuality and conflicts inherent to the parent-child relationship, Chang examines the territory of the primal, parental connection in her work In Love (2001). In this dual-channel video, two separate scenes of the artist with a parent are juxtaposed. Chang faces her mother and, in the adjacent frame, appears face–to–face with her father. Simultaneously both images show the artist’s and respective parent’s faces pressed together in what at first appears to be a deep kiss. Gradually it becomes evident that the video is running in reverse time, and that they share not a kiss but rather an onion from which they both eat. They bite into it slowly, pausing as they take turns offering it to each other, as if it suggests the proverbial, forbidden fruit. Parent and child swallow before they take additional bites, blinking hard to hold back tears from the onion’s sharpness and pungency. However, in the video’s reversal of time, the onion is reconstituted and the tears disappear—wholeness is thus regained. Held in the collection at the Guggenheim.

‘In this video, I share eating an onion with my mother and my father. The video is played backwards so that we begin in a kissing embrace with tears in our eyes. As the video plays, the tears roll back up and an onion emerges from our mouths. As the title suggests, the video is about the abstract boundaries of love, sacrifice, familial relations and inheritance.’ Patty Chang

end.title: Breezeblocks - Alt-J (2012)
end.brief_description:
A music video was created to accompany the release of the song Breezeblocks by Alt-J. Directed by Ellis Bahl and starring actors Jonathan Dwyer, Jessica DiGiovanni, and Eleanor Pienta, and it is the band’s first official music video.

The video features a violent fight in an apartment between a male and a female character shown in reverse, beginning with the death of the female character at the hands of the male character, who bludgeons her with a breeze block. As the fight progresses backwards, it is revealed that the female character is the aggressor in the fight, having ambushed the male character as he returned home to discover his presumptive wife bound and gagged.

The video aired for the first time on YouTube on 23 March 2012. As of October 2019, it has over 199 million views. The video won at the UK Music Video Awards for “Best Alternative Video” on 8 November 2012.

results.name: Hack the planet
results.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

key_work.title: Hacknet
key_work.creator_credit: Fellow Traveller and Team Fractal Alligator
key_work.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

start.title: ALB - Whispers Under the Moonlight (2014)
start.brief_description: This music video for ALB’s ‘Whispers Under the Moonlight’ claims to be the world’s first ‘Trojan Horse Music Video’. In order to initially play the video and take part, users download a file to their computer which then initiates a series of benign computer takeovers as part of an interactive art installation on the users computer.

start.creator_credit: Kirsten Johnson, Dirk Wilutzky, Laura Poitras, Mathilde Bonnefoy, JustFilms / Ford Foundation, RADiUS-TWC and The Bertha Foundation
start.headline_credit: Germany, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2014
start.brief_description: Laura Poitras blurs the line between documentary and investigative journalism. Poitras was one of three journalists confided in by whistleblower Edward Snowden when he shared classified documents that detailed global government surveillance. Telling his story earned Poitras a Pulitzer, while Citizenfour won an Oscar.

links.description: While in exile in Russia for the events taking place in Citizenfour, Snowden co-created the music video Exit that expounds on the dangers of surveillance culture.

end.title: Code Names (2001-present)
end.brief_description: Trevor Paglen’s Code Names exists as a list of words, phrases and terms that designate classified military programs. These include classified exercises and units, intelligence programs, information compartments and Pentagon “Special Access Programs.” Installed in downtown Syracuse, Code Names functions as a meditation on language and advertising whose product is foreign to the general population. The contents of the piece become metaphors for the unknown and ask the audience to ponder what exactly they mean.

constellations_other.name: Orwell & Snowden
constellations_other.description: Explores Orwell as a representation of the NSA, and the infamous Snowden leak.

links.description: Trevor Paglen’s ongoing video work Code Names is a scrolling list of words that designate classified military programs, and includes many coded names from the Snowden NSA leak. Paglen also was one of the key cinematographers for Citzenfour.

results.name: The Australian industry
results.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

key_work.title: True History of the Kelly Gang
key_work.creator_credit: Alice Babidge, Brad Feinstein, Hal Vogel and Liz Watts
key_work.brief_description: True History of the Kelly Gang is a 2019 British-Australian biographical western film based on the exploits of Australia’s famous outlaw, Ned Kelly. It’s directed by Justin Kurzel, from a screenplay by Shaun Grant, based upon the 2000 novel of the same name by Peter Carey.

constellations_primary.name: The Australian industry
constellations_primary.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_primary.name: Alice Babidge and True History of the Kelly Gang
constellations_primary.description: An acclaimed set, costume, and production designer in the world of theatre, Alice Babidge has most recently been working in film including Justin Kurzel features Snowtown and True History Of The Kelly Gang.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

start.title: The Nightingale
start.creator_credit: Bruna Papandrea, Jennifer Kent, Kristina Ceyton, Steve Hutensky, Adelaide Film Festival Investment Fund, Creative Wealth Media Finance, FilmNation Entertainment, Made Up Stories, Screen Australia, Screen Tasmania, South Australian Film Corporation, David Smith and Evans Mark
start.headline_credit: Australia, Canada and United States of America, 2019
start.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Some like it hot
constellations_other.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

end.title: Sweet Country
end.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
end.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Outlawed
constellations_other.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Released in the same year, both featuring extended hunts for revenge, Sweet Country and The Nightingale can be seen as sister films, part of contemporary Australian canon.

video_links.name: THE FAVOURITE | Official Trailer | FOX Searchlight

start.brief_description: England, early 18th century. The close relationship between Queen Anne and Sarah Churchill is threatened by the arrival of Sarah’s cousin, Abigail Hill, resulting in a bitter rivalry between the two cousins to be the Queen’s favourite.

constellations_primary.name: Auteurs and Yorgos Lanthimos
constellations_primary.description: Oscar-winner Sandy Powell crafted Abigail's (Emma Stone) costume in The Favourite to represent her ascension in the royal household of Queen Anne by utilising black and white.

constellations_other.name: Creating characters with Great costumes
constellations_other.description: Emma Fryer's costume design for The Great took inspiration from both accurate finery of the period, and contemporary designs of fashion houses like Dior. The resulting costumes evolve with the characters.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Dress to impress
constellations_other.description: In The Great, Peter and Catherine’s costumes during their Dacha visit are designed to demonstrate their unity, as they negotiate with the Swedish royals. Clothes have long been a way to communicate power, particularly in politics.

constellations_other.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up
constellations_other.description: The upper echelons of society explored through colour, make-up and scandal.

constellations_other.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_other.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

end.brief_description: Feature film adaptation of Shakespeare’s Scottish play about General Macbeth whose ambitious wife urges him to use wicked means in order to gain power of the throne over the sitting king, Duncan.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

links.description: Production designer Fiona Crombie and art director Alice Felton met while working on Macbeth. They went on to work together again on The Favourite, for which they were nominated for an Oscar, and David Michôd’s The King.

end.title: Judy & Punch
end.creator_credit: Edie Kurzer, Danny Gabai, Michele Bennett, Nash Edgerton, Create NSW, Pariah Productions, Screen Australia, Soundfirm, VICE Media and Mirrah Foulkes
end.brief_description: In the anarchic town of Seaside, nowhere near the sea, puppeteers Judy and Punch are trying to resurrect their marionette show. The show is a hit due to Judy’s superior puppeteering but Punch’s driving ambition and penchant for whisky lead to an inevitable tragedy that Judy must avenge.

end.title: Fortnite
end.brief_description:
Fortnite is the living, action building game from the developer formerly known as Epic MegaGames. You and your friends will lead a group of Heroes to reclaim and rebuild a homeland that has been left empty by mysterious darkness only known as “the Storm”.

Band together online to build extravagant forts, find or build insane weapons and traps and protect your towns from the strange monsters that emerge during the Storm. In an action experience from the only company smart enough to attach chainsaws to guns, get out there to push back the Storm and save the world. And don’t forget to loot all the things.

links.description: Fleischer’s use of rotoscoping to appropriate dances from performers of colour such as Cab Calloway has a 21st-century parallel in smash-hit videogame Fortnite, which has received numerous lawsuits from artists and performers claiming that the game has used their dance moves without compensation or credit.

end.brief_description: On a golden afternoon, young Alice follows a White Rabbit, who disappears down a nearby rabbit hole. Quickly following him, she tumbles into the burrow - and enters the merry, topsy-turvy world of Wonderland! Memorable songs and whimsical escapades highlight Alice’s journey, which culminates in a madcap encounter with the Queen of Hearts - and her army of playing cards!

end.title: Garth Marenghi's Darkplace
end.creator_credit: Charlie Hanson
end.brief_description: When the Hellmouth opens beneath Darkplace Hospital in downtown Romford, kiddy doctor, Vietnam veteran and ex-warlock Dr. Rick Dagless M.D. (Garth Marenghi) is the only man who can close it. Joined by best buddy Dr. Lucien Sanchez (Todd Rivers), fiery hospital boss Thornton Reed (Dean Learner), and woman Liz Asher (Madeleine Wool), Dagless must fight the forces of Darkness while dealing with the burden of day-to-day admin. From the chilling pen of best-selling horror writer Garth Marenghi comes this lost masterpiece of televisual terror. Dare you enter Garth’s Darkplace?

results.name: The Lumière brothers
results.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

key_work.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
key_work.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

constellations_primary.name: The Lumière brothers

start.title: Find Me a Māori Bride
start.brief_description: Find me a Māori Bride follows the comic misadventures of Tama Bradley, and his cousin George Alpert, a pair of successful, metrosexual Māori men, whose lives are turned upside down, when presented with a wero (challenge), by their late grandmother – find a Māori wife within 6 months, or lose out on inheriting the whānau farm, worth a whopping $47,000,000.

end.brief_description: Find me a Māori Bride follows the comic misadventures of Tama Bradley, and his cousin George Alpert, a pair of successful, metrosexual Māori men, whose lives are turned upside down, when presented with a wero (challenge), by their late grandmother – find a Māori wife within 6 months, or lose out on inheriting the whānau farm, worth a whopping $47,000,000.

start.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
start.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

links.description: The Lumière brothers The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896) was one of the first films exhibited theatrically. Legend has it that the audience were terrified and ran to the back of the theatre as the life-sized train approached.

end.title: Rad Racer
end.brief_description: This is no ordinary game pak. This is Rad Racer. Nintendo’s thrilling 3-D video game Rad Racer comes action-packed with revolutionary 3-D technology and 3-D glasses (they’re free inside) that will have you really believing you’re in the middle of a cross-country rally race - cruising along at 200 miles per hour! Rad Racer takes you through 8 treacherous race courses including the Los Angeles Nightway, the San Francisco Highway and the Grand Canyon. Choose the Ferrari and you’ll enter a Super Machine competition where you’ll race against Corvettes and Lamborghinis. Select the F-1 Machine and you’ll compete against incredibly fast cars. Whether it’s Ferrari or F-1, 3-D or regular mode, Rad Racer’s hairpin curves, daredevil turns and realistic action will bring home all the fun and excitement of real rally racing. Think you’re up to it? Then drivers, start your engines. It’s Rad Racer!

end.title: Tools of the Trade
end.credit_line:
Paint brushes

Courtesy Gary Kurzer

Scissor collection

Courtesy Edie Kurzer

Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020
end.brief_description: Angled. Flat. Tapered. Striker. Brushes come in as many varieties as the tasks they perform on film and television sets. Whether that’s a buffer brush used to smooth the lines of an actor’s makeup, or a mop brush with a rounded edge for soft paint application on a drying prop, they are an essential, albeit overlooked, presence in moving image production. Scissors are another one of those integral items; from the different sized sewing shears used by costume cutters to the razor-sharp blades designed to cut anything from wires to duct tape, they’re an invaluable tool for crew members across every department.

constellations_other.name: Clothing, country, character
constellations_other.description: Edie Kurzer's costume design work on Judy & Punch and Picnic at Hanging Rock is part of a larger trend in Australian films and TV series.

links.description: One of the most essential parts of Edie Kurzer’s process is to have the rights tools for creating her amazing costumes and artworks. You can see them on display in our Fed Square foyer.
